This is a great sequel to the original that expands greatly upon the original.  Unfortunately, that's both for better and for worse.  There's more of a focus on narrative, and it's really up to individual taste as to whether that's good or bad, but it plays well into the whole adventure.  You get to explore new areas in the testing facility, and learn more about the history of the company, mostly delivered through old recordings that sound like some sunshiney thing from the 1950s.  The writing isn't quite as dark and twisted as the original, but I had quite a few good laughs.  The biggest problems are these areas in between, since it's often difficult to figure out where to go next, and the tests in these areas, which involve different kinds of special gel.  Instead of having the entire puzzle already designed for you, you have to decide where the gel has to go to finish the puzzle yourself before solving it.  To make things worse, these rely heavily on physics, so even with the correct solution, you might wind up dying, anyway, because it just didn't work that time.  That left a bad taste in my mouth, but that was just a portion of the game; the climax and conclusion were good enough to wash it out, and overall, it was a good experience.

The second game in the series Portal 2 builds upon the established mechanics of the previous game, and enhances them. The game is difficult, but not infuriating. You "think with portals" to solve puzzles to progress farther through the game. You have to fight prior foes over again along with new enemies that you must survive. The previous game didn't have much in terms of story, but Portal 2 cracks that up to an 11 by creating a overarching narrative that sucks the player in with comedic and compelling characters. 

Overall its an 8/10 I would recommend this game.
